title: 111_hr4846
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bleeding Disorder Screening, Awareness, and Further Education (SAFE) Act of 2010". The Congress finds that millions of Americans may have an inherited bleeding disorder, with Von Willebrand Disease being the most common. Many remain undiagnosed due to outdated diagnostic methods. Symptoms may become apparent during adolescence, but individuals often live with the health risks without realizing they have a bleeding disorder. Improved diagnosis of bleeding disorders, through expanded screening of adolescents, improved physician awareness, and additional research, could prevent unnecessary hysterectomies for women with undiagnosed bleeding disorders. Improved diagnosis of bleeding disorders in adolescents could prevent unnecessary hysterectomies for women with undiagnosed bleeding disorders. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will develop a screening questionnaire for diagnosing bleeding disorders in adolescents and young adults, and disseminate it widely in adolescent populations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will prioritize grants for screening high school and college students for bleeding disorders. Technical assistance may be provided for grant recipients. Appropriations are authorized for implementation. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2011 through 2015. SEC. 4. INCREASING AWARENESS AMONG HEALTH PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will conduct an education campaign to increase awareness about bleeding disorders among health professionals, with priority given to those caring for adolescents and obstetricians/gynecologists. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to grant recipients for planning and implementing activities. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2011 through 2015. SEC. 5. RESEARCH AND SURVEILLANCE. The Secretary will award grants to entities to enhance research on diagnosing and prevalence of bleeding disorders, especially among women, to improve symptoms and quality of life. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to grant recipients for planning and implementing activities related to bleeding disorders. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2011 through 2015. SEC. 6. REPORT. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 5 years of this Act's enactment, detailing activities related to bleeding disorder screening, health professional education, and surveillance. The report must include information on the progress achieved, the number of students screened for bleeding disorders, and the healthcare professionals educated on bleeding disorders. The report to Congress, within 5 years of the Act's enactment, must detail activities on bleeding disorder screening, education, and surveillance. It should include progress, number of students screened, and healthcare professionals educated. Recommendations for future bleeding disorder activities should focus on improving screening and education programs to increase diagnostic rates and reduce the burden of undiagnosed bleeding disorders. Recommendations for future bleeding disorder activities should focus on improving screening and education programs to increase diagnostic rates and reduce the burden of undiagnosed bleeding disorders. The report should also identify organizations and programs that have effectively increased bleeding disorder screening rates and describe the services provided by hemophilia treatment centers. In this Act, the term "State" includes the District of Columbia and any commonwealth, territory, or possession of the United States.
